overall_score_comment: This song has the lyrical depth of a bumper sticker collection from a gas station in 2003.
the_roast:
Let's start with the absolute audacity of sampling Dionne Warwick's 'Walk On By' just to say 'bitch, I said what I said' over it. That's like using the Mona Lisa as a placemat for your McDonald's. The entire hook is literally 'I'd rather be famous instead' repeated until our ears file for a restraining order. Congratulations on discovering the 'copy-paste' function, truly revolutionary songwriting.

The verses are a fascinating psychological study in what happens when you throw darts at a board covered in 2010s rap clichés. 'She the devil, she a bad lil' bitch, she a rebel' — oh wow, we've never heard THAT particular combination of words in literally every single hip-hop track since 2015. And then 'she put her foot to the pedal' because apparently we're writing Fast & Furious dialogue now? The rhyme scheme of devil/rebel/pedal/settle is so lazy it's practically in a coma. You could've had a middle schooler write this in detention and they would've at least tried to use a thesaurus.

'I put good dick all in my kidneys' is perhaps the most anatomically confused flex in music history. That's not how any of this works. That's not how any of this has EVER worked. Someone needs to send this to a medical school as an example of what NOT to say about human biology. And then we get 'My illness don't come with no remedy' — so your illness DOES come with a remedy then? Double negatives aren't just bad grammar, they're accidentally revealing you might actually need help. The whole 'magical foresight' to see yourself 'sleeping in courtside' is peak accidental honesty: yes, we can all foresee you napping at a basketball game because this song is putting us to sleep too.

The bridge goes full word salad with 'I'm a two-time bitch, you ain't knew I'd win?' which sounds like autocorrect had a stroke. And the final plot twist of 'Fame ain't somethin' that I need no more' directly contradicts the ENTIRE SONG where you literally said 'I'd rather be famous instead' 47,000 times. That's not character development, that's just forgetting what you wrote three minutes ago. This song has the narrative consistency of a fever dream and the lyrical sophistication of a fortune cookie written by someone who's never actually experienced fortune.

cliche_counter.quip: The holy trinity of every SoundCloud rapper's vocabulary since 2014
And then you said it again. And again. And again. We heard you the first 8 times.
An idiom so old it predates the invention of actual red paint
Because 'pedal to the metal' was just TOO creative to use correctly

cliche_counter.cliche: Haters/opps waiting for me to fail
cliche_counter.quip: The persecution complex is strong with this one, unlike the originality
For someone who doesn't need things, you sure spent a lot of words telling us about it

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I put good dick all in my kidneys
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Aggravated assault on anatomy and biology
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory enrollment in 9th grade health class

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: She put her foot to the pedal / It'll take a whole lot for me to settle
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Rhyming a word with itself and calling it bars
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to write 500 actual rhymes using a rhyming dictionary

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: My illness don't come with no remedy
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Double negative that accidentally admits you DO have a remedy
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: One semester of remedial English grammar

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I'm a two-time bitch, you ain't knew I'd win?
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Murdering the English language in cold blood with 'ain't knew'
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Community service teaching ESL classes to learn proper verb conjugation

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Fame ain't somethin' that I need no more (after saying 'I'd rather be famous instead' 100 times)
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Contradicting your entire thesis statement within the same song
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to write a 5-paragraph essay on 'narrative consistency' before recording again

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a deep meditation on the duality of man and the postmodern condition of celebrity in late-stage capitalism. Just kidding — it's about being famous and saying 'bitch' a lot. The repetition is obviously a commentary on the cyclical nature of existence and definitely not just running out of things to say after the first verse.
final_verdict: This song is what happens when you put 'bad bitch energy' into a lyric generator and hit 'repeat' until you reach radio length. It's a masterclass in saying absolutely nothing with maximum confidence, which honestly? Kind of iconic in its own catastrophically empty way.
title: Paint the Town Red
